Posts.Content: pp729 wrote: Hi all, I have posted here before since I'd experienced breast pain beginning about 6 weeks ago and an ultrasound showed a solid mass.  I know that I have "dense breasts" and have had cysts show up on mammos and US in the past.  I had an ultrasound guided core biopsy last Thursday.  The BS called this morning and faxed me the report.  Good news - benign mass.  The biopsy report says "Benign breast tissue with stromal fibrosis, nodular sclerosing adenosis, usual type ductal hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia." A big relief for me, especially since my mom was diagnosed with Stage IIIb IDC last year.  My breast still hurts but I will just get used to that.  Thanks to you all for your help and thoughts/prayers in the past 6 weeks.  This board is such a great resource with an amazing group of women. Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 09:29AM pp729 wrote: WorriedHusband, I just found this post and read through it.  The waiting time for a pathology report for my mom was about 7 to 10 business days (excluding weekends of course).  So if your wife had the surgery on May 2nd, you will probably be hearing something this week? My biggest suggestion to you is to make sure you ask for a copy of the pathology report when it comes in -- it contains a wealth of medical info that you can use to educate yourself whether it is breast cancer or not.
Posts.Title: Wife has Hard Lump worriedhusband FilterLady

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 09:12AM pp729 wrote: Worried husband, I have been following this thread and others -- my mom was diagnosed with Stage 3 BC last year and I am currently awaiting a biopsy to be scheduled on a solid mass found in my breast.  So, I have educated myself a great deal over the past year or so.  I concur with everyone else -- call the doctor and ask to speak directly to him/her,  have a pen and paper ready and write down everything they say, and have them repeat/spell anything you are unclear on.  I would suggest you get a spiral bound notebook to keep all your notes in.  That way you have it at your ready everytime you need it.  I have one with my mom and it has been very helpful to us both.  I also prepare a list of questions every time before she sees a doctor, has a procedure, etc.  That way, I feel like I am remembering everything that I wanted to ask.  (yes, I know, I tend to go overboard on most things) I would also ask them to send me a copy of the biopsy report/pathology report -- it will be very detailed and then you can search for things it says. If you have a fax machine, get them to fax it to you.  If not, ask them can you come to pick it up if you feel uncertain about them actually mailing it to you.  The more you know, the more you will be able to help your wife and answer all your questions.  Good luck to you, I know it's worrisome but you are being a great advocate for your wife!!
Posts.Title: Wife has Hard Lump worriedhusband FilterLady

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2012 01:26PM pp729 wrote: Hi worriedhusband,  since your wife has already had a biopsy, I'd suggest you get a copy of the pathology report and see what it says -- you'll see information describing the area they looked at and particularly the area that is in question. In addition, after the lumpectomy, there will be a second pathology report that you should ask for.  In both cases, they are looking at the cells from the samples and tissue that are taken.  The pathology report generally takes 3 to 5 business days after the procedure.  This website, as well as the NIH website, the Mayo Clinic website, and others have info on how to read the pathology report once you have it.  It's a wealth of information.  Enjoy the weekend and Father's Day -- I know Monday will be looming but you'll have all the information you need in about a week or so.
Posts.Title: Wife has Hard Lump worriedhusband FilterLady

Posts.Content: pp729 wrote: Hi ladies.  My mom is a Stage 3 BC survivor (2 years out) and I have fibrocystic and dense breasts and have had two suspicous masses biopsied, most recently in June 2012. Fortunately, both were benign.  I just had my final follow-up with the BS this month, and so now I can return to my regular OB-GYN.  During the session with the BS, she used a calculator to tell me that my BC risk is 19% -- which she described as slightly higher than normal due to my mom's BC and my fibrocystic breasts.    We talked about medications that I am taking -- Tri-legest FE BCP which I have been on for many years (In fact, I have been on a BCP for probably 30 years or more now.)  Plus, I take a soy supplement called Estroven Max for night hot flashes (yes, I am stilll perimenopausal at age 51).  The BS was not thrilled that I am taking the Estroven -- mainly because she said it is a manufactured soy and there is no data that says that it reduces hot flashes.  For me, I feel like it does on the week when I am on the BCP placebo (week 4) and having a period and when the hot flashes are awful.  So, I do feel it works for me then.  She suggested that I go off the Estroven Max and talk to the OB-GYN about a different BCP. But I am confused by this because the Tri-legest FE is a very low dose BCP and I am hesitant to change to a different one.  It's also inexpensive and I have never had any side effects.  At the same time, I do not want to be taking anything that would increase my BC risk.  Have any of you ladies read or heard anything about the affects of taking a soy supplement or a BCP on cancer risk? My mom:1/2011 Mod. Diff. IDC;Focal dermal lymphatic involvement;ER+99%;PR+98%;HER-2/NEU Neg;BR=9/9=Gr 3;Ki67=80%;Oncotype=36; 4/11 Unil. Masc;benign nodes;Stg 3b; 4/19 Recurrent IDC,dermal lymphatic invasion,bone metastases,ER+100%;PR+66%;HER2-;Stg 4 Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2013 08:07AM pp729 wrote: Thanks ladies.  I will talk to my OB-GYN about this when I see her next month.  I am confused that the BS recommended me to go off the soy supplement, but remain on the BCP (perhaps changing the type to assist with the hot flashes).  Any idea why she would have not just said to go off both? MelissaDallas, yes I am still perimenopausal -- I have the FSH test every year and I am still having periods on a random basis (although my cycle has never been regular).  I also had endimetriosis and this particular BCP and some others that I was on before was indicated to treat that. It's a "low dose" BCP so at least I am getting mcg of estrogen instead of the usual mg dosage in regular pills.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 05:55PM pp729 wrote: Zohra, I was just where you are 2 years ago with my mom.  And, like everyone else said, it is a personal decision that your mom has to make.  For my mom, she opted to have only a single mastectomy and no breast reconstruction.  It was a fairly easy surgery and healing process for her and in fact, she tried to convince the doctor to let he go home the night of the surgery (of course, he kept her overnight for observation).  I stayed with her a week after the surgery just to make sure everything was okay, but it was not necessary.  Just wanted to stay there and be sure. Having said that and with 2 years in hindsight, my mom does say that she wished she'd have had a double mastectomy.  Part of it was that she was just so afraid of the surgery and what they might find going into it that she did not.  Now, she sees her ONC every three months and has bloodwork then, as well as occasional scans.  But, she still has the concern that the BC would return in her other breast. Good luck to you and your mom.  If she goes with what her heart is telling her, she can't go wrong.
Posts.Title: stage IIIB and mastectomy need advice pls zohra pp729

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2012 01:56PM pp729 wrote: Hi dmnw, I respect your decision not to have a marker, but I will tell you that I chose to have one during my core needle biopsy in early June.  My mass was very small, and thankfully was benign.  I have very dense breasts and the June biopsy report showed fibrosis, adenosis, usual type hyperplasia, and metaplasia.  I have also had issues with cysts in the past and had a Fine Needle Aspiration in 2007.  My mother was diagnosed with Stage IIIb BC last year.  I had pain in my breast and thought I felt something, although my OB-GYN and Breast Surgeon did not.  The mass showed up on an ultrasound, but did not show up on two mammograms prior to the biopsy.  In fact, the surgeon had a bit of a difficult time finding it at first via US during the biopsy.  So, we talked about this during the procedure, and I decided to have the marker implanted.  My reasoning was that I have very dense breasts, this mass was not seen on multiple mammos, and I wanted them to be able to easily locate this area in the future should I have needed surgery.  Thankfully, I did not as the mass was benign but I still feel better knowing that they can easily locate this area by mammo and US, if there is an issue in the future. I am sure that if you call around to doctors in your insurance network, you will be able to find one who will respect your wishes not to have it.  It may take some effort on your part, so good luck with that.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 11:06AM pp729 wrote: Sorry you are dealing with this with your mom, but this board will be very helpful to you as it was with my mom and I.  I have to echo the other post here -- most definitely get a second opinion at a reputable cancer center.  Not sure where you are, but it is even worth a long drive or flight to take your mom somewhere if necessary.  My mom is in SC, but I took her to Fox Chase in Philadelphia for a second opinion.  She is also Stage 3 (IIIb) but her lymph nodes were clear, and they still recommended both chemo and radiation because of her aggressive form of cancer.  The two tests you want to determine the aggressiveness of the cancer is the Ki67 and the OncoType DX tests.  Insist on them now as they do take a while to be done -- particularly the OncoType which will tell you the benefit of chemo or no chemo.  Also, if your mom is ER+, she should be started on drug therapy by now (Tamoxifen if she's premenopausal or Arimedex if she's post).  Good luck and my prayers to you and your mom.
Posts.Title: Stage III but they say no chemo? Good news, but is it accurate? Pinkfuzzysocks34 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2011 05:09PM pp729 wrote: Just wanted to chime in that sometimes the doctors are a bit tentative at first, and it makes sense that they are because the may be trying not to overload your mom with too much information and also because there is a myriad of tests that they will run.  So it's like putting together a big jigsaw puzzle and the information does come in in waves.  With my mom, sometimes I found that the information that her Breast Surgeon gave her about chemo or radiation did not exactly match what the Medical Oncologist or Radiation Oncologist said.  She also had some disagreement between the MO and the RO.  But the BS most always said to her that the MO would be the expert that she should rely most upon about chemo and the RO would be the one to rely on most about radiation. (So the BS really just focused on the surgery aspects).  In addition, we did get second opinions both for the MO and the RO, so having two sets of opinions was helpful.  The OncoType DX test was the most informative test that we had and I encourage you to ask for that.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 12:14PM pp729 wrote: My mom had the OncoType test -- it gives you a recurrence score.  A score of 18 or less is considered a low risk of recurrence and the benefit of chemo would be small.  A range of 18 to 31 is considered intermediate, and the benefits of chemo are more unclear.  A score higher than 21 is considered high risk and the benefits of chemo are likely.  It also gives you the 10-year chance (%) of recurrences for Tamoxifen only and for Tamooxifen plus chemo.  Its a test of 21 genes, so I would encourage you to get it done if you can.
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX questions BlazerFanC Jamie30

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 08:14AM pp729 wrote: Hi Lady Pak, looks like your mom has been diagnosed and had a unilateral mastectomy, just like my mom did in 2011.  Your Onc will give you the Stage and a treatment plan when you see him as a followup to the surgery. That may include chemo, radiation, and/or post surgery medications. Meanwhile, one of the best resources that I found with the help of this forum is the NCCN guidelines at: www.nccn.org Click on NCCN Guidelines at the top and then select NCCN Guidelines for Treatment of Cancer by Site, then select Breast Cancer, then select NCCN Guidelines (it's a PDF file). You will have to set up a login name and password to be able to open the PDF file, and you will need your mom's pathology report to work your way through the slides to get to where her particular type of cancer is.  Good luck as you go through the process -- your mom is so lucky to have you to help her.  Mine is NED after a year, so she is doing well and I am hopeful that your mom will have the same outcome.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 07:05PM pp729 wrote: SpecialK -- thanks for the suggestion about the ultrasound-guided aspiration.  That is what I had done on a cyst in my right breast in 2007.  It was a very simple procedure then.  For this one, if the mammo cannot help them distinguish if it is a solid mass or a cyst, the BS said she may order a US-guided aspiration (also called a FNA) first and an ultrasound-guided core biopsy as a second alternative.  That way they start with a FNA and only go to a core biopsy if they need to ----- all in the same procedure.  Much depends on what they see on Monday with the mammo and compare it to the ultrasound that I had last week. FioreTD - I think I can feel the lump, but neither my OB-GYN or the breast surgeon could.  It may just be that I am feeling some of the denser breast tissue that I have or that I am mistaken about feeling it.  Your BS will have the results of the ultrasound in less than a day.  The BS can give you a copy of the report written by the radiologist who reads the US, and then you can do some research on this website and others.  Mine specifically said what it was and that a US-guided core biopsy was recommended along with a BIRADS 4 (suspicious) rating.  The BS that I saw was very through -- she showed me the US films, discussed the US report, did an evaluation, and then walked me through her recommendation for mammo first (since I have not had one in almost a year), and the plan for a biopsy.  I went in with a list of questions about the biopsy and she covered them all for me, then when I got into my car, I wrote notes so I would not forget things.  (Yes, I am a bit anal about things).  If you feel more comfortable bringing someone with you to the appointment, I would say by all means do so.  We do that with my mom's BS and oncologist visits -- someone always goes with her because she feels better having a second set of ears. Hope this helps you and I know the waiting is really hard.  Just remember, most masses are benign.  So I am sending out good wishes to you.  Keep us posted on how your appointment goes.
